_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary



Facility:    MFA Anhydrous Ammonia Plant

Location:    1770 Lee Avenue, Jackson, Mo. 63755

Contact:     David Wichern

Phone:         573-243-3549



1. The Facility Policy



MFA Incorporated and the employees of the MFA Anhydrous Plant in Jackson are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Cape Girardeau LEPC, Jackson Fire Department, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2. Facility Information



The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of anhydrous ammonia for direct application as a crop nutrient.



The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a transport delivery truck holding approximately 50,000 pound.   



3. The Accidental Release Prevention Program.



The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, 1999", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia regulations and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". The facility will work to meet the newest codes as time and budgets allow.



4. The Five-year Accident History



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



5. The Emergency Response Program.



    The facility has;

        a. a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 

              1910.38;



        b. provided State and Local authorities with the emergency planning

and 

              community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III 

              EPCRA);



        c. employees will not respond to any release other than to activate an emergency

            shut-off while evacuating the facility. Local emergency responders will be  

            notified to control any release.



6. Planned changes to improve safety.



Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Currently the facility is evaluating the requirements of CGA 2.1-2014 and Process Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals and will make the required upgrades as needed.







    4/7/16
